column1: Will the Harvard Crimson defeat the Yale Bulldogs in "The Game" in 2022?
column6: ['Sports']

Pushing this back up given Yale - Harvard's last 20 years of matches at Home have had a 7-2 record in favour of Harvard + yale isn't great this year at away games, like Harvard isn't great at home games. However, given that this game is being played at Harvard's home + Yale's streak is mostly driven by great home performance, I would give the edge to Harvard.
Looking at the most recent developments on both sides, I feel like there's now a higher likelihood that Yale will win The Game

As much as it pains me to reduce this. Harvard's wins are coming on away grounds + coupled with Yale's streak, I would tilt this otherwise even contest in Yale's favour. Will be there and cheering for the crimson red regardless :)
Yale seems a little bit better with its player and team statistics. I have nothing else to go on.

according to actionnetwork.com: Harvard are 4-1 in their last 5 games. Harvard are 0-5 in their last 5 games against the spread. Harvard are 2-3 in their road games against the spread. The totals have gone OVER in 3 of Harvard' last 5 games . The totals have gone OVER in 1 of Harvard' 4 last games at home. Yale are 4-1 in their last 5 games. Yale are 2-3 in their last 5 games against the spread. Yale are 2-2 in their road games against the spread. The totals have gone OVER in 2 of Yale' last 5 games. The totals have gone OVER in 2 of Yale' 5 last games at home.
Updating due to Yale's winning streak and currently superiority in the rankings

Yale has been on a 3-W streak and doing better overall at 7W-2L, versus Harvards (6W-3Ls). Additionally Yale recently won against Brown and Princeton whereas Harvard lost against both teams this season.
Adjusting based on the team's current records
Yale is now placed 1st in the league rankings. They defeated yet undefeated Princeton in the last game. Harvard is 4th in the ranking now.
Yale's recent win over Princeton suggests that they are the better team.
Hedging my Yale victory slightly, given Harvard’s strong showing last weekend against Penn (who beat Yale), but the Bulldogs still appear the better team.
historical data.
The coaching prowess of the Harvard side. In individual games Harvard have performed well overall, even against those Yale may have had a greater average point score in games.

Updating my forecast to reflect how Harvard and Yale have been doing this season. Harvard's overall record this season is 6-3, while Yale's is 7-2. Further, the Game will be a home Game for Harvard but their Home record is 1-3.
Currently Harvard has a better record and they will home field advantage for the game, and is thus favored to win.
Looks like Yale will probably win, but I had to rise above (or elbow aside) my family's Harvard leanings to actually go public with that. . . .

Yale looks like a stronger team lately: They beat Princeton and Columbia, while those two beat Harvard at Harvard Stadium. They have also been more consistent than Harvard. All of those lead to the higher possibility that Yale would beat Harvard.
Yale is ranked higher in the Ivy League, has beaten more opponents who beat Harvard than vice-versa, and has wins in the match-up historically. All the same, Harvard beat Merrimack so I am wary.

Yesterday's games offer no new insights other than that both teams played well to beat opponents that previously defeated the other rival earlier in the season. I maintain my forecast that Yale is slightly favored but reduced my confidence based on yesterday's results.

Adjusting downward from the latest weekly stats from Yale (https://yalebulldogs.com/sports/football/stats?path=football) and Harvard (https://gocrimson.com/sports/football/stats?path=football)--the former has realized a winning streak, as the latter has losing one. What's catching my eye at this juncture is attendance at each game for these two teams and the propensity of them winning or losing. I see the Harvard-Yale game as a "big" event, and with 30,323 capacity for Harvard Stadium most likely going be filled, how will Harvard respond to such a crowd? Will it help them in support or hurt them--home court advantage? What about Yale?
Updating to coin flip

Historically extrapolating past games gives insight into who wins - Harvard tends to take the cake. Though the majority of instances are closely matched, there are games where the discrepancies are high, where as of the four games Yale has won since 2003, only one had a large discrepancy in the score.
Yale is ranked 3 in the Ivy League and Harvard is 4.

Harvard beat Yale last year, but it was a close game (34 – 31). Harvard had a better season overall than Yale last year. Further, Harvard will be playing at home and might be more likely to play better due to this home court advantage. Nevertheless, the Bulldogs have been having a good season this fall. These factors lead me to assign a 70% probability to the Crimson beating the Bulldogs in The Game in 2022.
Since my last update, Yale won with significant differences to its rival, and Harvard lost narrowly with Columbia.
Given Yale’s leading record and history of beating Harvard, I am leaning far more heavily toward Yale
Yale has been doing well lately
Adjusting given that Columbia beat Harvard and Yale beat Columbia.

In using pair-wise comparison, we can rely on the statistics from previous games not only between Yale and Harvard, but from the games of each team against others within the conference. The scores outputted from the conference games demonstrate that Yale tends to win against teams that Harvard has lost to this season, proving a higher likelihood that Yale's team is better than Harvard's. Moreover, Yale has traditionally won "the game" more frequently than Harvard.

Harvard lost to Columbia today while Yale thumped Brown by a wide margin. The offenses remain well-balanced by the turnovers and penalties still favor Yale. I increase my confidence in Yale to beat Harvard in a fortnight.
Adjusting since Columbia (a team Yale beat) beat Harvard today, and Yale beat Brown today by way more than Harvard did. (Though I'm still rooting for Harvard).

In reviewing the historical record of Harvard’s face-off with Yale, I discovered a 45% base rate; however, college football can often be a toss-up regardless of either team’s record, especially in a high-stakes game with a lot of pomp and circumstance. As a Texan, I’d be remiss in not drawling a parallel to the Texas-OU game – the Red River Rivalry – which happens in Dallas every year and in many ways represents the pinnacle of college football in the South. Regardless of either team’s record, it’s anyone’s game, and little beyond bragging rights are on the line.
Updating since Yale beat Columbia pretty bad, and Columbia played a pretty even game with Dartmouth, who Harvard beat but by less than Yale beat Columbia. I think it's really a pretty even toss-up.
Looks like the odds I found were from the 2021 game actually so I need to reset my guess.
Outside in: The chance of any team winning a match is 50%
Ooh, what a stumper. Yale leads the overall 68-61 (ties? meh), but the game is in MA, both teams are 5-2, and have streaks of W1. I expect to keep adjusting this as the game nears.

Over the past two decades Harvard has won more games than Yale. Within the past season, Harvard and Yale both played Cornell and Holy Cross. Harvard lost against Holy Cross at a lower margin than Yale, however Yale lost against Cornell at a lower margin. This indicates that performance in the past season is neck to neck. However, as Harvard is on home turf, I am giving the slight advantage of victory to Harvard.

Given that Yale historically leads Harvard in wins, my prior is that Harvard has a higher probability of losing the 2022 game. However, when looking more in depth at how Harvard has performed in the past few years, I found out that Harvard won last year and had a much better season than Yale, and I’m assuming most of the players/coach to be the same this year. As of this year, Harvard and Yale are performing the same, with two losses against the same teams (Holly Cross and Penn). In addition, Harvard will be playing in the Harvard stadium for the first time in years, which adds to the probability that Harvard will win this year. In the next few weeks, I will have to track injuries and each team's performance in the remaining games before the Harvard/Yale game to update my forecasts.

the teams currently (10/30) have the same record. they've lost to the same teams (Holy Cross 8-0 and Princeton 7-0). the last couple of weeks both have lost and then won. i'll monitor next weeks games both are host H hosts columbia who just lost to yale 41-16, and yale host Brown who just upset previously undefeated Penn. I would say Harvard is a big favorite to beat coumbia and yale should be big favorite against Brown.
The teams seem fairly evenly matched to me, with Harvard enjoying a small edge.
According to historical data, in the last 70 games Harvard has wone 10 of the 30 Harvard-Yale games in Harvard Stadium.
Though both the teams are evenly matched, home field advantage gives more chances for Harvard team.

This is a major event: this competition didn’t take place at the Harvard stadium for a while, which could result in additional home-game motivation from the Harvard side. In past years, when Harvard won it was because they won more consistently in the earlier matches, but this year both teams lost to the same opponents (Yale and Holy Cross). In the last 5 years, Yale won 3 times and Harvard 2. Before that, Harvard consistently won more frequently. The competition is very close.

Looking at the last 5 years of games worth of data, I forecasted that based on the proportion of wins that Harvard has a 40% likelihood of beating Yale. The reason I used a timeframe of 5 years is the football coaching staff and players continuously fluctuate and change, but 5 years gives you a pretty good snapshot of the performance of the current player recruitment pool and staff.

On October 29, Harvard beat Dartmouth on the road by a score of 28-13. Yale also beat Dartmouth earlier in the season but by fewer points. Harvard's offense was weighted heavily toward their run game. I still side with Yale but increase Harvard's relative chances in the game. Yale did not play this weekend.

Regrettably, I will go against my school. I take only statistics from this season that started on September 16. I think the Yale Bulldogs have a better chance of winning (60%) versus the Harvard Crimsons. My rationale is that I see more effectiveness in annotations from Yale to Harvard (49 vs. 16).

• Started with a base probability of 70%, given that Harvard has won 70% of the last ten games. Felt all-time history was less relevant and it would be more important to look at the recent past for reference.

To start, I pulled 20 year game history between Yale and Harvard. From here, I marked each game played over the course of the last 20 years (less 2020 due to pandemic) on which team won, what the score differential was for each game, and where it was played. Seeing as Yale leads the all-time rivalry here—but over the course of the last 20 years Harvard leads 16 wins to Yale’s 4; this year’s “The Game” will be played on our turf at Harvard for the first time since 2016, there will be—I am assuming here—some degree of “home court advantage” to account for. For these preliminary reasons, I am marking a 70% Yes outcome to this question.
Harvard also has the home game advantage with the crowd cheering them on, and there may still be some of the same players from the last two games (where Harvard did well)

Yale has a slight edge in terms of history, but the past 4 years have been evenly matched and the past 15 years has seen Harvard win more. I believe that this momentum puts the odds slightly in favor of Harvard Crimsons.

Harvard and Yale have a somewhat matched overall record while playing each other, with Harvard at a slight disadvantage since 1875. Harvard has a 16-4 lead in the past 20 years, but 3 of Yale’s wins were in the past 5 years. Taking into account the dynamics of Harvard and Yale’s wins when playing home games and not, I forecast a 55% probability of Harvard winning.
Harvard hasn't had a home game since 2018. and has had 7/10 last wins. I decided to update my forecast with this information more in favour of the Harvard win
Although Yale has won more games against Harvard, Harvard has had a longer winning streak over the last few years.

Harvard may have historically had a lower win against Yale, it seems probable that it could break the 4 win streak of Yale and win on the home ground (both could work as extra motivating to get the win). However, I'm not pegging the probability too high considering that Yale is on a winning streak, and on a lead which they would do everything to maintain.
I also considered home games (Harvard wins more if it’s a home game), took into account performance for most recent years, and looked at overall ranking.
Moving closer to a more even game. Tickets are sold out very early. Wonder if the difference in resale value indicates anything about level of home field advantage...
- Harvard has exhibited a winning streak since 2000 (Yale only won 5 out of the 21 matches).

Win record of last 10 games: Harvard 7, Yale 3. Narrowing down to the last 5 games: Yale 3, Harvard 2. Both teams are evenly placed in their overall head-to-head, recent games, as well as the standings in the current season. We cannot adequately predict the momentum going into the match since both sides will be playing matches within the league before they meet each other. There isn’t a significant home advantage at play either. In the last 5 games, 3 matches have been won by home teams and 2 matches have been won by the visitors. What would need to happen for one team to beat the other? We can look at the injury record, the strength of the team going in, and whether players on this team have played the other in the past. Both Tim Murphy for Harvard and Tony Reno for Yale have been head coaches for a while now with Tim starting this year as the best-winning coach in the Ivy League of all time. Given a minor home advantage, also keeping in mind my personal bias, the strengths of the coaches, team, current standings, past record, and how keenly these matches have been contested, I’ll likely give the stronger probability to Harvard.
Over the past 30 years, Harvard won 2/3 of games against Yale, so we can start with a prediction of 67%.

Beginning with the historical record sets up a very broad sense of the matchup, moving to a ten year history pulls more recent performance into view, and adding this current year's record adds the most recent data. That number comes in at 59% which is simply too high in context of the current year's record. The record indicates both teams are fairly good with both probably having a chance at the victory. Harvard's advantage of being the home team shouldn't be discounted--every NFL season, except COVID, has shown a home field advantage.

I looked at how many games Harvard has won over the past 20 years compared to Yale. Harvard has won 15 of the past 21 games so I benchmark around 70/30 Harvard win. Additionally, I note that this game will take place at Harvard and therefore home team advantage increase the probability that Harvard will win compared to Yale. Finally I research team composition for this year of Yale and Harvard team. Harvard has lost 2 home games and won 1. Yale has won 1 away game and lost 2 and their overall stats are both 4-2.
For my analysis I will use the following steps within the context that the composition of a college football team changes much faster than a professional team.

There are a number of issues that affect my forecast: the historical record between the two times as the base rate, the performance in recent Harvard-Yale matches, as well as the record of the two teams and current league standings this season. In addition, from an inside view, I am considering additional factors such as injuries or other short-term tactical developments.
I’ll start with an outside-ish view. I don’t think a very broad question like “how often does any football team win games in November?” is relevant.

- Usually home teams have advantages but Harvard hasn’t shown any such home team advantage (with a 1-2 record at home). - Both teams are in the middle tier of the Ivy League at the moment - The reason I give Yale a slight advantage is because facing first tier teams Penn and Princeton, Yale had a tighter score than Harvard vs Princeton suggesting that perhaps its defense is slightly better.This forecast should be better after the next two week’s games.
Given the past few games, the fact that a game hasn’t happened at Harvard stadium in a WHILE, and the fact that the game is at Harvard, I predict a higher chance of Harvard winning. Link used here.
Since this Q is sponsored by the Kennedy School, there is sure to be bias in the aggregate forecasts of others.

There’s a base rate of 45% given the entire record. But winning the game seems like a complete toss up. While Yale has an edge in terms of total wins since 1875, in recent years, since 2014, for example, it’s been back and forth. This season, Yale has won 4 games and lost two. It’s won 1 away game and lost 2, so it has a worse away game record. Harvard has the same record, however, it has won all three of its away games. This year, the game is held at Harvard. Given this, I have placed a slightly higher percentage for Harvard winning given the energy they will have at home.
Updating to account for Harvard having a home team advantage, which will support Harvard through fans. And Yale tends to do worse on the road.
Game is not at Fenway Park, so adjusting to factor that out.

I looked at ESPN's analysis of both teams' performance over the season and I see that Harvard has had stronger numbers in terms of passing, rushing, and receiving yards, all key indicators of high performance. Therefore I am upwardly updating my predictions.
Base rate for Harvard to win is 44.5% over the full series. However, of the last 10 games, Harvard has won 7. Of these 10, Harvard won 3 of the 4 games played in Massachusetts.

The historical base rate for Harvard winning against Yale over the past 137 games has been 49.63%. Thus far in this year's season, Yale has averaged 6.5 points and 419 Yards per game, with a total number of 26 penalties. In comparison, Harvard has averaged slightly fewer points with an average of 5.3 points, 384.8 yard per game, and a total penalty count for the season higher than yale with 39 penalties. Given this slightly worse track record for the season, I would reduce the odds of Harvard winning from the base rate by a few percentage points.
Because Harvard rules and Yale drools. :)
Last year, Harvard won at Yale and this year, they’re playing at home so that usually favors the home team.

In the last decade, Harvard has been showing better results than Yale, being clearly superior to Yale. However, I do not have much information about this year's formation. Given past performance, I would say Harvard is favored to win. Harvard won 5 games out of 7 games that were played in Cambridge.

Outside perspective wise, historical record doesn't really matter apart from recent few years because of team turnover. Two years ago the game was cancelled due to COVID, and Harvard won the away game last year.

Historically, over the last 4 years, Harvard and Yale have won an equal number of times. I’m considering the 4 year timeframe because teams churn in a 4 year period – so any results data before that is irrelevant since those team members are no longer around.
Key factors:

Game is at Harvard and there is a slight benefit to playing at home. Sports betting sites given Harvard a 53 percent chance of victory but given I am a Harvard student I wanted to increase the chances slightly. I don’t want to consider past Yale/Harvard outcomes because that would be the gambler’s fallacy.

While both teams currently have the same record (4-2) as of the weekend of 10/23, they both have played three common teams (Holy Cross, Cornell and Howard) and both have lost against Holy Cross and beat the other two, there are three reasons: 1- Harvard has the historical record (which sometimes is just a fun fact), 2- Harvard is playing at home, so homefield advantage and 3- versussportssimulator.com gives Harvard a 52% chance of winning
we don't know the composition of the team for 2022, so I adjusted down
Adjusting for ELO rating and home advantage, and using the same formula as 538.

Record: I believe the outside view starts with this year’s record as an anchor, because this year’s teams will play each other (not prior teams full of completely different players under the same banner). Harvard and Yale are both 4-2 on the season, and 2-1 in conference. However I am more interested in games where they played the same opponent. Both teams lost to Holy Cross, but Yale lost by more (-24) than Harvard (-9). Both beat Cornell: Harvard (+7), Yale (+24). Both beat Howard: Harvard (+16), Yale (+8). In the three games they played the same team thus far, Harvard has a total point differential of +14 and Yale of +8. Implication: With identical records on the season and in conference, Harvard has a slight advantage in point differential, but all numbers are incredibly similar.Historical Analysis: As a long-time fan of college sports, I know not to put much stock in historical records – teams change so significantly year-to-year, that I put the greatest stock in this year’s performance, with some additional analysis of the last two years (since some coaches, players, playbooks, team dynamics will remain similar). I believe a pitfall will be looking too deeply at historical trends. Harvard won last year at Yale (this year Harvard has home field advantage), but the win was only by three points. The 2020 game was cancelled due to COVID. Yale won in 2019 in two overtimes. Implication: These results are nearly even.Expert Analysis: Most betting sites I read gave a slight edge to Harvard.Home Field Advantage: The game will be played at Harvard, and this research (and others) demonstrates that the phenomenon of “home field advantage” is scientifically and statistically grounded: https://www.chicagobooth.edu/review/home-field-advantage-facts-and-fiction. But it also indicates that people tend to overstate how much it matters – it provides a slight advantage.Conclusion: It’s sports – anything can happen. That’s why we love sports. The two seem pretty evenly matched. I’m going with a slight edge to Harvard because of home field advantage, stock in experts who know more than me, and a higher rated defense and run game (which can be even more of an advantage in a more conservatively-played game, which high-stakes games usually are).
The last game Harvard won, and according to betting sites, there is a slight edge for Harvard.
At first, statistics didn’t look too good for Harvard (68-61-8) but a closer look at the number shows

I believe Harvard will beat Yale. Since 2012 (last ten years), Harvard has beat Yale 6/10 times. Also, Harvard has home field advantage. The data shows that of the last 10 home games, Harvard has won 8/10 times. Given that players change (on both teams) and Harvard and Yale have similar records for this season, I’m predicting 55% probability that Harvard will beat Yale.
1. My baseline is 49% for Harvard winning the game, built from 4 following facts, averaged with same weight:

Historically, Yale has been the winner, although Harvard beat Yale last year as a visitor in CT and in 2018 won at home at Fenway Park. However, I think Yale is slightly more likely to win as it has won 50% of the 137 historical games played since 1875 (Harvard has won 45% and there has been a tie in 5% of the cases).
Harvard has a historic win but particularly over the last years consistent wins.

I started anchoring my probabilities by thinking how often Harvard defeats Yale in “The Game”. Over time, both teams have had a similar number of wins (68 versus 61), but Yale has had a slightly better performance than Harvard (49.6% versus 44.5%). In the last 20 years, Harvard has won 16 times, against only 4 wins for Yale (80% versus 20%). However, in the last 5 years, Yale has won 3 times and Harvard only 2 (60% versus 40%).

Historically, Yale has won 49.6% of times against 44.5% of Harvard. Over the past five years, Yale has won three times against two for Harvard. None of them has won by a significant margin over the past two games (there was no game in 2020). The last game was won by Harvard with a narrow lead of 3 points. This indicates that both teams are very competitive and there is a slight lead of Yale over Harvard. As they are playing in Harvard territory this time and as Yale has won already in 60% of the last five occasions, I give Harvard a slight lead to win this time.
Yale has historically won more, but this season it's a close call.

While Yale leads Harvard in wins since 1875, that doesn’t really matter; what we should be looking at is the score over the last 2 years (because many of those players will likely still be at the respective schools). Last year, Harvard won (but just barely). In 2019, Yale won. I would give the edge to Harvard because it is a “home game,” so 60% makes sense to me.

It doesn’t make sense to use the total record since 1875 as a baseline prediction, because so much has changed over the past century-and-a-half and it barely makes sense to suggest that either of the schools’ football programs are comparable to how they were in the distant past. Choosing any date from which to count the record would be at least somewhat arbitrary, but I want a large (and recent) enough sample to get a realistic sense of the teams’ relative chances. Therefore, I look at the past 30 games and see that Harvard has won 20 times. Therefore, my baseline is 66.666%, rounded up to 67%.

-6.5 odds in Crimson favor, which implies ~70-75% in Harvard's favor. The teams seems to have different strengths, Harvard's run game and run defense look better. It is still sports though, so anything can happen.

While Yale has the overall alltime record, Harvard has won 5 of the last 7 Games played in Cambridge, with Yale’s only away victories coming in 2006 and 2017. Harvard won the last Game, played last year in New Haven. Yale sits in 4th place of the Ivy League with a middling 2022 record, and Harvard, 3rd. With both teams having mediocre seasons, I think home field advantage will make the difference here. Harvard to win.
I don't know anything about this sport, but my usual strategy is to root for the team that has the fewest letter areas that can be filled in in pen.

Harvard is 1:2 at home and 3:0 away. The game is at home, which gives Harvard the home field advantage. Yale is 3:0 home and 1:2 away. It is hard not to forecast for Harvard, so I am admittedly biased. Harvard is ranked higher today for offense, but Yale’s defense is ranked slightly higher than Harvard. Overall Harvard is ranked 3 in Ivy League and Yale is ranked 5. https://ivyleague.com/stats.aspx?path=football&year=2022 Harvard crushed Yale the last time they played at “home” at Fenway Park in 2018. Harvard has won 2 out of the last 3 games against Yale. https://ivyleague.com/stats.aspx?path=football&year=2022

Statistically, there is not much difference between the two teams so far this season. They have the same records and share the same results against common opponents (losses to Holy Cross, wins against Cornell and Howard). While Harvard has a more balanced offense between running and passing, Yale holds an advantage in time of possession. This suggests that Yale may gain an advantage by limiting Harvard’s scoring opportunities. Another meaningful difference is in turnovers. Harvard has 13 total turnovers while Yale only has 6. Again, advantage Bulldogs. Finally, let’s look at penalties. The Crimson have committed 47 (almost 8 per game for over 70 yards) while Yale has only committed 38 (almost 2 fewer per game) for roughly 60 yards per game. Two penalties and 20 yards could be the difference in such a tightly contested game. I bet on Yale at this point.

I think it's basically a toss-up. Overall this season, Harvard and Yale are both 4-2 overall and 2-1 in their conference. What’s more, Harvard and Yale have both beat Cornell and Howard and lost to Holy Cross. I tried to find betting odds but did not succeed. Last year Harvard beat Yale 34-31. I considered giving Harvard an additional boost because of home field advantage, but they have already dropped two games at home this season so that doesn’t seem to have a strong effect. The Yale-Princeton game the weekend before could be informative (Harvard lost to Princeton 37-10 on Friday 10/21).

The base rate for this forecast is the all-time record of 68-61-8. This base rate has Harvard winning 61 of 137 games (44.5% rate). A quick review of the 2022 season (as of Oct 20) shows that Harvard has won 4 of 5 games (80%), and Yale 6 of 10 games (60%). There are also two different sports forecasters who put Harvard ahead in the whole season of yale (https://theanalyst.com/na/2022/08/fcs-college-football-preview-ivy-league/ and https://www.ctinsider.com/sports/article/Yale-football-picked-fourth-in-Ivy-League-17359184.php). Based on this, I’m updating the base rate to having a higher percentage of a Harvard win.

Looks good at the moment. In deference to those participants in this forum who still think the Yankees or the White Sox will win the World Series, though, I've put ten bucks on Florida in the Harvard-Yale game.

While Yale historically has won more games against Harvard, they are currently ranked lower than Harvard in the Ivy League conference (Harvard is 3rd; Yale is 4th) and are coming off a very mediocre 2021 season (5-5). I think the game is essentially a toss-up though because both schools have a 2-1 record right now, but I’ll give Harvard the edge because of the conference ranking.
Dawgs will be geared up, Crimson will wilt.
